reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2013, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Checked in early afternoon and had a wander around the city. Hotel is elegant. Staff all seem very young, pleasant and friendly. Room exquisite, linen and toiletries lovely, bed a bit soft for our liking, complimentary mini bar with 2 soft drinks 2 bottles of water, a packet of crisps and a kitkat and plenty of room for your own additions! Unfortunately our room overlooked the stage door of The Academy and the staff seemed to congregate outside there to chat and smoke. We heard some noise during the night when they were loading up the vans but no more than you would expect from being in a busy city centre. After a meal and an and evening at the theatre we decided to have drinks back at the hotel. We ordered two Bombay Sapphire and tonics, total cost £12 and were disappointed as we were both unable to taste the "gin". Needless to say we retired to our room to consume our own drinks.
reviews.title: very impressed

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2012, traveled on business
reviews.text: The restaurant becomes a Marco Piere White establishment for lunch & dinner which sadly i never got to experience. I did have the pleasure to take breakfast though & had they dish up probably the best sausages i have had in ages & proper flat mushrooms rather than the more usual button ones. The charming staff constantly top up your orange juice. On the (only slightly) down side, the queues do build at the self-service coffee & toast point at busy times. This is a tad of a poor side to an otherwise flawlwss service. The bar is not cheap but the stylish furniture, atmosphere & service made it all worthwhile

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: This was the first time I enjoyed my accommodation in Newcastle. I have travelled there for work several times, and I have stayed in hotels and B&B's which have ranged from very bad to average to 'OK good'. Indigo is a very good boutique hotel, that wins hands down when compared to some of the other big chain holels I have used in this city. The hotel is located centrally, near the train station, restaurants, and other amenities. The price is reasonable for the quality of accommodation (I paid £99 per night). The hotel also features a Marco Pierre White restaurant which I didn't try - but the atmosphere was warm, lively and sophisticated when I arrived to check in at 11:30pm on a rainy night. The reception staff were very friendly and helpful (and alarmed, as I slipped on my way to the reception! luckily more a comedy moment than an accident) The room is of a good size, modern and stylish. The bed was extremely comfortable (I could do with a bed like that at home, in fact). It was well made with crisp clean sheets, and very welcoming. There was a stylish black and green armchair and a stool, which were a little cramped (the bed is massive and quite high). The room was also fully kitted with good lighting, a flat screen TV, an ipod/iphone deck, and connections so you can plug in your camera etc. The bathroom is also great, with good quality towels and Aveda toiletries. Unfortunately one of the glasses I had was dirty, so that put me off a bit. That was the only slip though... I still had a very comfortable and cosy stay at Indigo, and I would definitely return there on my next trip to Newcastle.
reviews.title: Great city hotel with great friendly service

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2013, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Booked a 2 night stay B&B flexible rate. Arrived before scheduled check-in and gladly our room was already available. Check-in was quick. Room was located on 2nd floor. Clean, tidy and fresh. Everything we needed was there - quality towels, robes, hairdrier, safe, iron/board, minibar with water, soft drinks and chocolate, very comfortable bed, wifi, tea/coffee, etc. Needed for nothing. Only thing perhaps missing are slippers! Breakfast on Saturday was a hot and cold buffet, on Sunday it was a cold buffet with a selection of hot breakfasts made to order. Absolutely nothing to fault as concerns breakfast and breakfast service. Quite a popular hotel as we noted lots of other guests plus people coming to the bar and the MPW restaurant in the evenings. No hesitation about recommending this hotel to anyone. Walking distance to City Hall, train station, the Tyne, shopping, bars, restaurants, etc. 20mins taxi ride to airport.
reviews.title: Would stay again - no question!

reviews.text: This was a Christmas present so I went with my sister in law . Apart from the fact that they had me booked in for Monday instead of today the problem was quickly rectified and were seated without a hitch . I love the buzz of this restaurant and it was equally good for the tea . We were offered an extensive choice of teas and the food was delicious . The cake stand had sandwiches, quiche, two scones each with jam and clotted cream, chocolate eclairs , a fruit tart , a Victoria sponge , a small very rich chocolate ganache tart , and a delicious raspberry mousse served in an expresso cup. It was a very big afternoon tea and we took some home which wasn't problem . The staff are very pleasant , we were not hurried , lots of people were having champagne as well as the tea so it caters for all tastes . A very enjoyable afternoon and compares very well with J D H ......

description: Hotel Indigo Newcastle is just a two-minute walk from Central Station, and a ten-minute walk to Newcastle United Football Club. This upscale venue features an iconic Marco Pierre White Steakhouse, delivering to our guests a refreshing and welcoming experience.Hotel Indigo is a boutique concept by InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG), offering guests the luxury and individuality you would come to expect of a 4-star hotel. The design of the venue has been heavily influenced by its location within the historic Grainger Town area and will feature bold geometric forms, classical proportions and repeating patterns to mimic the architecture and rows of columns that can be seen around the local neighbourhood. Today, the Grainger town area is a hot-spot for cutting edge architecture and just a short stroll away from the city’s art galleries, restaurants, shops, bars and business district. Hotel Indigo Newcastle has a car park at the rear with charges at £12 per night.
